perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a 2-year non-competition period. Reducing this to 6 months may be considered unreasonably short under British Columbia law (where the contract is governed), potentially making it unenforceable, especially if it harms Western Copper's ability to compete effectively after the agreement.

perturbation.original_text: Glamis covenants and agrees with Western Copper that if at any time it intends to dispose of a Designated Mineral Property for cash consideration or by abandonment, it will give Western Copper notice (the ‘ Disposition Notice”) of the intended disposition. For a period of 30 days from the time of delivery of the Disposition Notice Glamis will, if requested by Western Silver, entertain an offer from Western Copper to acquire the Designated Mineral Property. In the ease of a Designated Mineral Property that Glamis intends to dispose of for cash consideration, the parties will negotiate in good faith to reach a mutually agreeable agreement for the sale to Western Copper of the [Designated Mineral Property. If Glamis and Western Copper are unable to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral Property within the 30 day period, Glamis may thereafter dispose of the Designated Mineral Property as it sees til in its absolute discretion. If Glamis does not dispose of the Designated Mineral Property within a period of 3 months from the first to occur of the date that Glamis and Western Copper acknowledge failure to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral Property and the end of the 30 day period, the provisions of this section 2.2 will once again apply to any intended disposition of the Designated Mineral Property by Glamis. In the case of a Designated Mineral Property that Glamis intends to abandon, Glamis wall, if requested by Western Copper, transfer such Designated Mineral Property to Western Copper at no cost save and except for the reasonable costs of transfer incurred by Glamis.
perturbation.changed_text: Glamis covenants and agrees with Western Copper that if at any time it intends to dispose of a Designated Mineral Property for cash consideration or by abandonment, it will give Western Copper notice (the ‘ Disposition Notice”) of the intended disposition. For a period of 5 days from the time of delivery of the Disposition Notice Glamis will, if requested by Western Silver, entertain an offer from Western Copper to acquire the Designated Mineral Property. In the ease of a Designated Mineral Property that Glamis intends to dispose of for cash consideration, the parties will negotiate in good faith to reach a mutually agreeable agreement for the sale to Western Copper of the [Designated Mineral Property. If Glamis and Western Copper are unable to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral Property within the 5 day period, Glamis may thereafter dispose of the Designated Mineral Property as it sees til in its absolute discretion. If Glamis does not dispose of the Designated Mineral Property within a period of 1 month from the first to occur of the date that Glamis and Western Copper acknowledge failure to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral Property and the end of the 5 day period, the provisions of this section 2.2 will once again apply to any intended disposition of the Designated Mineral Property by Glamis. In the case of a Designated Mineral Property that Glamis intends to abandon, Glamis wall, if requested by Western Copper, transfer such Designated Mineral Property to Western Copper at no cost save and except for the reasonable costs of transfer incurred by Glamis.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the period for Western Copper to respond to a Disposition Notice from 30 days to 5 days and the period Glamis has to dispose of the property from 3 months to 1 month may not provide Western Copper with adequate time to assess the opportunity and secure financing, potentially violating the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing in contract law under British Columbia law. This could be argued as hindering Western Copper's ability to exercise its right of first offer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing under British Columbia Contract Law.
